unnormalised: New Delhi, Oct 26 - Fuel efficiency is becoming a major selling point in the Indian automotive market. Dr. Meena Sharma, a professor at IIT Madras specializing in automotive engineering, notes that advancements in engine technology and vehicle design are significantly improving mileage.
normalised: New Delhi, October twenty sixth - Fuel efficiency is becoming a major selling point in the Indian automotive market. Doctor Meena Sharma, a professor at I I T Madras specializing in automotive engineering, notes that advancements in engine technology and vehicle design are significantly improving mileage.

unnormalised: "We're seeing a shift from purely focusing on power to prioritizing fuel economy," she states. Recent tests conducted by ARAI (Automotive Research Association of India) show some models achieving over 25 km per liter under optimal conditions.
normalised: "We're seeing a shift from purely focusing on power to prioritizing fuel economy," she states. Recent tests conducted by A R A I (Automotive Research Association of India) show some models achieving over twenty five kilometer per liter under optimal conditions.

unnormalised: Government initiatives like the Bharat Stage VI emission standards are also pushing manufacturers to innovate. Car manufacturers like Tata Motors are investing heavily in R&D, exploring lighter materials to reduce vehicle weight. This includes incorporating components made with advanced polymers which decrease body weight significantly.
normalised: Government initiatives like the Bharat Stage six emission standards are also pushing manufacturers to innovate. Car manufacturers like Tata Motors are investing heavily in R and D, exploring lighter materials to reduce vehicle weight. This includes incorporating components made with advanced polymers which decrease body weight significantly.

unnormalised: Consumers are increasingly aware of the long-term savings associated with fuel-efficient vehicles. A recent survey in Mumbai revealed that 70% of respondents consider mileage a crucial factor when purchasing a new car. With rising fuel prices (Rs. 110/liter in some areas), even a small improvement in efficiency can translate to substantial savings for the average driver covering 1500 km monthly. This translates to savings on parking spots that require 150 sq ft of space on average.
normalised: Consumers are increasingly aware of the long-term savings associated with fuel-efficient vehicles. A recent survey in Mumbai revealed that seventy percent of respondents consider mileage a crucial factor when purchasing a new car. With rising fuel prices (rupees one hundred and ten per liter in some areas), even a small improvement in efficiency can translate to substantial savings for the average driver covering one thousand five hundred kilometer monthly. This translates to savings on parking spots that require one hundred and fifty square feet of space on average.
